name: 1607_A. Linear Keyboard
description:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys. The keys are arranged sequentially in one row in a certain order. Each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter.

You have to type the word s on this keyboard. It also consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To type a word, you need to type all its letters consecutively one by one. To type each letter you must position your hand exactly over the corresponding key and press it.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right). No time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively. Therefore, it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74

prompt:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys set up in sequence in one row in a particular order, where each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter. You have to type the word s on this keyboard, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To type a word, you must type all its letters consecutively one by one. It is essential that you position your hand precisely over the corresponding key. Proper positioning of your hand over the key is necessary to type each letter. Only after you have positioned your hand can you press the key and type the letter.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right), and no time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively, so it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s. Remember to consider the initial positioning of the hand before typing the first letter as part of the time calculation. Ensure to account for any predefined order in which the keys are arranged that might not necessarily follow the typical 'a' to 'z' sequence.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74
repair_prompt:
You are given a keyboard that consists of 26 keys set up in sequence in one row in a particular order, where each key corresponds to a unique lowercase Latin letter. You have to type the word s on this keyboard, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters.

To type a word, you must type all its letters consecutively one by one. It is essential that you position your hand precisely over the corresponding key. Proper positioning of your hand over the key is necessary to type each letter. Only after you have positioned your hand can you press the key and type the letter.

Moving the hand between the keys takes time which is equal to the absolute value of the difference between positions of these keys (the keys are numbered from left to right), and no time is spent on pressing the keys and on placing your hand over the first letter of the word.

For example, consider a keyboard where the letters from 'a' to 'z' are arranged in consecutive alphabetical order. The letters 'h', 'e', 'l' and 'o' then are on the positions 8, 5, 12 and 15, respectively, so it will take |5 - 8| + |12 - 5| + |12 - 12| + |15 - 12| = 13 units of time to type the word "hello". 

Determine how long it will take to print the word s. Remember to consider the initial positioning of the hand before typing the first letter as part of the time calculation. Ensure to account for any predefined order in which the keys are arranged that might not necessarily follow the typical 'a' to 'z' sequence.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Write a main() function and use input() function to read input from stdin

from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {char: idx for idx, char in enumerate(keyboard)}
    
    # Initialize the total typing time with the time to position the hand on the first letter
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the initial positioning time for the first letter
    initial_position = keyboard_positions[word[0]]
    
    # Iterate through the word to calculate the movement time between consecutive letters
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_position = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        movement_time = abs(current_position - keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]])
        total_time += movement_time
    
    # Add the initial positioning time to the total typing time
    total_time += initial_position
    
    return total_time

# Read from stdin
import sys

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(sys.stdin.readline().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Read the word to type
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    # Calculate the typing time
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    # Output the result
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the time to position the hand before typing the first letter
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_letter = word[i]
        next_letter = word[i + 1]
        current_position = keyboard_positions[current_letter]
        next_position = keyboard_positions[next_letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - next_position)
    
    return total_time

# Read from stdin
import sys

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(sys.stdin.readline().strip())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the time to position the hand over the first letter
    total_time = abs(keyboard_positions[word[0]])
    
    # Calculate the time to type the rest of the word
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_position = keyboard_positions[word[i]]
        previous_position = keyboard_positions[word[i - 1]]
        total_time += abs(current_position - previous_position)
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

import sys

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time with the time to position the hand for the first letter
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the word
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_letter = word[i]
        next_letter = word[i + 1]
        current_position = keyboard_positions[current_letter]
        next_position = keyboard_positions[next_letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - next_position)
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases

# Process each test case

    keyboard = input().strip()
    word = input().strip()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    position_map = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        position_map[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the total typing time
    total_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the time to type the first letter (initial positioning)
    first_letter = word[0]
    total_time += position_map[first_letter]
    
    # Calculate the time for the rest of the letters
    for i in range(1, len(word)):
        current_letter = word[i]
        previous_letter = word[i - 1]
        total_time += abs(position_map[current_letter] - position_map[previous_letter])
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each key to its position
    key_positions = {}
    for index, key in enumerate(keyboard):
        key_positions[key] = index
    
    # Calculate the initial positioning time (time to position the hand over the first key)
    initial_position = 0
    
    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    total_time = 0
    for i in range(len(word)):
        if i == 0:
            # Initial positioning time
            initial_position = key_positions[word[i]]
        else:
            # Movement time between keys
            total_time += abs(key_positions[word[i]] - key_positions[word[i - 1]])
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout and the word to type
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    
    # Calculate and print the total typing time for the word
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    """
    Calculate the time required to type a word based on a given keyboard layout.

    Args:
        keyboard (str): A string of length 26 representing the keyboard layout.
        word (str): The word to be typed.

    Returns:
        int: The total time required to type the word.
    """
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index

    # Initialize the total time with the time to position the hand for the first letter
    total_time = 0

    # Calculate the time for each consecutive letter
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_letter = word[i]
        next_letter = word[i + 1]
        current_position = keyboard_positions[current_letter]
        next_position = keyboard_positions[next_letter]
        total_time += abs(current_position - next_position)

    return total_time

# Read from stdin
import sys

# Read the number of test cases

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    word = sys.stdin.readline().strip()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    position_map = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        position_map[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the typing time with the time to position the hand at the first letter of the word
    typing_time = 0
    
    # Calculate the typing time for the word
    for i in range(len(word) - 1):
        current_pos = position_map[word[i]]
        next_pos = position_map[word[i + 1]]
        typing_time += abs(current_pos - next_pos)
    
    return typing_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    keyboard = input()
    word = input()
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {}
    for index, letter in enumerate(keyboard):
        keyboard_positions[letter] = index
    
    # Initialize the total time to 0
    total_time = 0
    
    # Initialize the position of the hand to 0 (assuming the hand starts at the position of the first letter)
    hand_position = 0
    
    # Iterate through each letter in the word
    for letter in word:
        # Get the position of the current letter on the keyboard
        current_position = keyboard_positions[letter]
        
        # Calculate the time to move the hand from the current position to the current letter's position
        time_to_move = abs(current_position - hand_position)
        
        # Add the time to move the hand and the time to press the key
        total_time += time_to_move
        
        # Update the hand position to the current letter's position
        hand_position = current_position
    
    return total_time

# Read input from the user
keyboard = input()
word = input()

# Calculate the typing time
result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)

# Print the result
print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

def calculate_typing_time(keyboard: str, word: str) -> int:
    # Create a dictionary to map each letter to its position on the keyboard
    keyboard_positions = {char: idx for idx, char in enumerate(keyboard)}
    
    # Initialize the total typing time with the time to position the hand for the first letter
    total_time = 0
    
    # Position the hand for the first letter
    current_position = keyboard_positions[word[0]]
    
    # Calculate the time for each subsequent letter
    for letter in word[1:]:
        next_position = keyboard_positions[letter]
        total_time += abs(next_position - current_position)
        current_position = next_position
    
    return total_time

# Read the number of test cases
t = int(input())

# Process each test case
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the keyboard layout
    keyboard = input()
    # Read the word to be typed
    word = input()
    # Calculate and print the typing time for the word
    result = calculate_typing_time(keyboard, word)
    print(result)

The requirements involve calculating the time required to type a word on a custom keyboard layout. The keyboard layout is provided as a string of 26 lowercase Latin letters, and the word to be typed is also provided as a string of lowercase Latin letters. The challenge is to determine the time taken to type the word, considering the initial positioning of the hand and the movement time between keys.

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

The first line of a description contains a keyboard — a string of length 26, which consists only of lowercase Latin letters. Each of the letters from 'a' to 'z' appears exactly once on the keyboard.

The second line of the description contains the word s. The word has a length from 1 to 50 letters inclusive and consists of lowercase Latin letters.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case is the minimal time it takes to type the word s on the given keyboard.

Example

Input


5
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
hello
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
i
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
codeforces
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq
qwertyuiopasdfghjklzxcvbnm
abacaba


Output


13
0
68
0
74
